Award.AwardTitle: Targeted Infusion Project Grant: Developing a Social Computing Program at North Carolina A&T State University

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Targeted Infusion Project entitled - Developing a Social Computing Program at North Carolina A&T State University - has the goal to establish a Bachelor of Science in Computer Science (BSCS) concentration in Social Computing. Graduates with training in social computing are prepared to inform empirical research, professional practice, and public and social policy as it pertains to both information technology and social change in a globalized society.

The project is a joint effort of the Departments of Computer Science, Mathematics, and Sociology and will strengthen partnerships among the departments. The project will create a new, interdisciplinary curriculum model for a BSCS concentration in Social Computing. Such a curriculum will allow students in the field of computer science to learn about social computing and social computational systems, allow students in mathematics to apply mathematics to social computing, and allow students in sociology and psychology to learn about social computational systems. New courses such as introduction to social computational systems, mathematics for social computing science, and social issues relating to social computing will be developed. The curriculum and instructional materials developed by this project can be adopted by faculty at other colleges and universities. The project team will host a workshop at the ASE/IEEE International Conference on Social Computing. The team will disseminate instructional materials for the new courses and introduce the software tools that were developed in the social computing lab. This project will increase the educational and career opportunities for African American students majoring in computer science, mathematics, and sociology at NCA&T State University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of this project was to develop a social computing program at North Carolina A&T State University (NCA&T). Societal benefits of this project include more educational materials and improved educational opportunities for training students to tackle tomorrow’s challenges in social computing. This project impacts our society through producing graduates to satisfy an ever-increasing need for professionals in social computational systems. With the government's growing interest in social computing and the increasing investment by social media organizations in technology, training in social computing or systems for social computing gives graduates some of the best career opportunities in today's economy. Graduates with this training are uniquely prepared to inform empirical research, professional practice, and public and social policy as it pertains to both information technology and social change in a globalized society. Moreover, as “information overload” and social networks increase, social computing becomes even more significant; the need for professionals with knowledge of the appropriate technology and its social effects will be critical to the healthcare, government, academic, and private and non-profit sectors. For example, social networks provide an ever-increasing field that requires coursework and training that can be obtained through a program in social computing.

The proposed project promotes a new model for an interdisciplinary curriculum for a social computing program. This curriculum produces graduates in computer science who have skills in social computing. It also allows students in the field of computer science to learn about social computing and social computational systems, allows students in mathematics to apply mathematics to social computing, and allows students in sociology to learn about social computational systems. The proposed project developed courses including social implication of computing, web science, and scientific computing.

To facilitate the social computing educational program, a laboratory for social computing program was developed using existing facilities of the interdisciplinary research lab (iLab) at NCA&T. The social computing lab provides hands-on exposure for faculty and students to learn about up-to-date developments in social computing and to conduct research in social computing. The laboratory provides experimental environments for various courses and research projects. The model for the curriculum and instructional materials can be adopted by educators in multiple disciplines such as computer science, information systems, mathematics, and sociology. This project increases the educational and career opportunities for African American students. As an HBCU, NCA&T is our nation’s leading producer of African American bachelors graduates in engineering. This project helps the students at NCA&T to be more competitive in the workforce and for admission to graduate school. It has a broad impact on students in multiple disciplines such as computer science, mathematics, and sociology.    

The dissemination plan consists of two phases. The first phase is to start communicating preliminary results on the development of the materials and modules for the course to faculty at NCA&T. Comments and suggestions were sought during that time and used to guide further improvements in the second phase, which targets faculty not only at NCA&T but also beyond and involves significant publications.
